Award.AwardTitle: Threatened Indigenous Languages: An analysis of tribal perspectives and responses

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Improved opportunities in STEM education must be coupled with supportive approaches and conditions to help students succeed. Studies have shown that students who are fluent in a tribal language have greater academic success than students who are semi-fluent in two languages. The enhanced academic performance of Native students in STEM studies will result in more indigenous STEM professionals entering the workforce, thereby both strengthening and diversifying the study and application of STEM knowledge. The work of this project will increase the body of knowledge around ways to preserve, foster, and restore Native languages, particularly among American Indian people.

Threatened Indigenous Languages: An analysis of tribal perspectives and responses, will investigate why and how indigenous communities (especially those with tribal colleges) promote the survival or revival of their ancestral languages. Although most language survival efforts focus on the specific task of recording and documenting threatened languages, this study will, instead, examine larger social and cultural forces in Native societies that encourage or inhibit community awareness and community-based action. Site visits will examine how various tribal communities perceive the value of indigenous languages, how these communities define language survival goals, and how they develop policies and programs to reach established goals. Finally, it will examine the degree to which current language survival efforts are succeeding and, based on these findings, to identify lessons learned and next steps.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Most of the world?s six thousand languages?including nearly all of the remaining indigenous languages found in the United States--are teetering on the edge of extinction. Overwhelmed by the growing dominance of English and several other ?global? languages, this rich heritage is being lost so quickly that, according to linguist David Crystal, a language is disappearing every two weeks. This loss is often likened to the rapid extinction of plants and animals.

However, unlike the disappearance of species, there is little public awareness of language loss and relatively little is being done to reverse this trend at the federal level. As the Washington-based Leadership Conference notes, ?It wasn't until the mid-1900s that the preservation of Native culture and language began to gain support, and several more decades before any legislation was passed to accomplish that goal.? Even now, funding for language preservation is a low priority within the United States.

Within Native communities, however, language loss is considered a serious issue and revitalization is emerging as a top priority. Dozens of tribes are actively working to document and teach their ancestral languages. With little visibility or support outside of Native communities, however, this revitalization movement is largely unrecognized and remains poorly understood.

The purpose of Native Language Survival: An analysis of tribal perspectives and responses was to develop a deeper understanding of the role tribal communities play in the maintenance and restoration of their own languages?how they articulate the value of language, how they identify goals, and how they assess, on their own terms, progress toward those goals. To investigate these questions, a case study approach was followed, focusing on close examination of three tribal and Native communities: the Fort Berthold Reservation of North Dakota, the St. Regis Mohawk Reservation of New York, and the Native Hawaiian community on the Big Island of Hawaii.

A strong and consistent finding was that Native language activists see their work as part of a larger agenda for tribal nation building. Within this common goal, some focus more on the ability of languages to build pride and promote cohesion within a community. For others, language revitalization is part of a more overtly political agenda to strengthen tribal sovereignty and even exist outside of the western political and economic systems.

In practice, many community-led initiatives are hampered by limited funding, a lack of teaching materials, the absence of trained language teachers, and inconsistent support from their tribal governments. Many programs, as a result, are restricted to teaching words and phrases, not grammar and conversation. In communities where immersion schools exist, students can achieve greater mastery of the language, although language activists note that without continued instruction and practice, skills erode and the revitalization project stalls. The challenge for these communities is to expand programs, coordinate existing language efforts, and build a wider base of community support.

Among the sites studied, Hawaii had the most comprehensive and most fully integrated language program. On the island of Hawaii, children have the opportunity to attend language immersion schools during all years of formal schooling, beginning with preschool ?language nests? and continuing into K-12 immersion schools that are part of the state?s public education system. Students also have the option of attending the College of Hawaiian Language within the University of Hawaii-Hilo where courses are also taught in the Hawaiian language. It is reported that students participating in this educational path do achieve fluency and there is some evidence that the language is being reintroduced into both home and community settings.

The Hawaiian model is often viewed as unrealistic for small tribes on the mainland, where support from state education systems is not available. However, follow-up analysis identified several aspects of the Hawaii model that can be replicated by even small tribal communities. These strategies include establishing private immersion schools, expanding language instruction within tribal colleges, and creating community-led non-profits to promote and coordinate revitalization work.
